awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: RUI: IRES: Birds, Beans, and Bugs - Modeling a Warming Climate's Effect on the Natural Enemies Hypothesis
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project small groups of graduate and undergraduate students from Humboldt State University and Missouri Western State University will engage with faculty in applied ecological research in Kenya.  The research will extend work from a previous IRES award and launch new collaborations with foreign partners.  The program has a unifying theme of investigating the effect of rising temperature on insect pests and their natural enemies in coffee farming landscapes.  Specific research questions will involve field sampling, computer modeling, and molecular analyses in the lab, thereby training students in several scientific methodologies.  

Students will take courses in the fall and spring semesters that will prepare them for, and aid their analysis of, field research conducted over 5-week field seasons in Kenya.  Students and professors will work in coordination with ornithologists and entomologists from Kenya's National Museums of Kenya and the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology.  The work will be integrated with classroom instruction, extending the benefits of the project to other students at our predominately undergraduate institutions.  Students will be fully immersed in the international research process, they will collaborate with foreign and U.S. mentors, and they will benefit from the program's unique integration of field- and classroom-based learning.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Birds are found foraging in agricultural landscapes throughout the world, but they often go unnoticed by farmers. This research project combined undergraduate and graduate students from Missouri Western State University and Humboldt State University to work with professionals at the National Museums of Kenya to identify how abundant and diverse the bird community and plant communities are in Kenyan coffee farms. We found that global climate change is projected to lower bird diversity in coffee farms, however growers that maintain shade trees on their land can help conserve bird species by providing suitable habitat. Moreover, these shade trees can help aid coffee growth under future climate predictions. We also discovered that the types of plants providing shade in these farms mattered, and that native Cordia trees are used by more bird species and attract more insect food resources than the non-native Grevillea robusta.

 

Overall, this award allowed fifteen students to conduct ecological research in Kenya and learn data analysis techniques. Students and PIs travelled to Kenya for about a month in December of 2017, 2018, and 2019. The award produced peer-reviewed scientific manuscripts and results have been communicated in local, national, and international conferences along with the farmers and managers that run the sampled Kenyan coffee farms. This research project yielded three Masters’ theses and two Honor’s undergraduate theses. As a result of this research experience, many participants are now pursuing graduate degrees in the sciences and are well-versed in collaborating internationally with scientists to perform cutting-edge research.


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Julie A Jedlicka

    Studying birds in Kenyan coffee farms
